posts.text:
Updated 10 minutes ago
ORANGE, Conn. (AP) — A Connecticut couple is facing charges after police say they engaged in sexual activity in a parked car with a 6-year-old boy in the back seat.
Police in Orange say two McDonald's employees were leaving the restaurant on Nov. 15 when they spotted two people engaged in sexual activity in the front seats of a car. They say the child was in the back seat, awake and alert.
Police say they arrived to find 28-year-old Kimberly Onorato partially undressed. Police say Onorato and 27-year-old Rory Clark stated they had only been cuddling.
Clark and Onorato are both charged with impairing morals of a minor and breach of peace. Online court records don't list lawyers for the pair.
The child was turned over to a relative. Police also contacted child welfare authorities.

posts.text:
× Couple accused of having sex in McDonald’s parking lot as 6-year-old watched 
ORANGE, Conn. – Two McDonald’s employees called police after walking out of the restaurant to find a couple in a parked car “engaged in sexual activity,” police said Monday. 
The workers had just finished their shifts at the Orange, Connecticut, McDonald’s around 9:30 p.m. on November 15, when they noticed the vehicle. One of the employees told a 911 operator it appeared the pair were having sex, and that “a small child was seated in the back, watching,” according to police. Kimberly Onorato, 28, and Rory Clark, 27, allegedly told police that they were “cuddling” after two McDonald’s employees called 911 to report two people engaged in sexual activity in the parking lot. (Town of Orange Police Department) 
When police arrived, they found a woman partially-naked in the front seat with a man, and a 6-year-old in the back seat who was “alert and awake,” WTIC reported. 
The couple said they were “cuddling” after eating at McDonald’s, according to police. 
Officers arrested Rory Clark, 27, of West Haven, and Kimberly Onorato, 28, of Bristol. Both were charged with second-degree breach of peace and impairing the morals of a minor. 
They were both released on $5,000 bond.

thread.title: Local McDonald’s need to hire security
thread.title_full: Local McDonald’s need to hire security

posts.author: Wire Service
posts.title: Local McDonald’s need to hire security
posts.text:
Local McDonald’s need to hire security Tue Nov 22nd, 2016 1:30am Opinion   
If anyone doesn’t know, the McDonald’s on Everett Avenue is a haven for drug dealers, the homeless and drug users who just languish around there all day, seven days a week. I refuse to give that establishment my business because of this, and I’m fed up. Recently, I went in there and asked to speak with a manager about this ongoing problem that seems to be ignored and continuously allowed. 
When I asked a manager why this keeps occurring without any positive changes to stop and combat this, he said that corporate won’t allow them to hire a police officer or security for this troublesome restaurant. I think that is a complete joke, so I guess my next step is to contact corporate McDonald’s about this location and the one on 41st and Colby Avenue. That location is just as bad, and I am assuming that corporate is refusing to spend money for security or a police officer there as well. They are losing customers and I hope other people complain about this too and speak up about this. 
Jeff Swanson

posts.text:
A McDonald’s assistant manager handed a bag to a customer this week. A burger and fries weren’t inside. 
Michael Anthony Acevedo is accused of trying to sell marijuana on the job, according to dailycommercial.com . 
Eustis police say they got a call about the manager handing a bag of drugs to a woman. When they confronted Acevedo, they found marijuana, a grinder and other drug supplies isnide the manager’s backpack, according to the report. 
He was charged with possession of marijuana arrested and released on $2,000 bond, according to the Lake County Sheriff’s Office. Related content

thread.title: Couple Arrested For Sex In McDonald's Parking Lot
thread.title_full: Couple Arrested For Sex In McDonald's Parking Lot

posts.author: Michael Howard
posts.title: Couple Arrested For Sex In McDonald's Parking Lot
posts.text:
A man and a woman were arrested in Connecticut after they allegedly had sex in their car in a McDonald's parking lot while a small child watched from the back seat.
Authorities say two McDonald's employees were leaving work around 9:30 p.m. on Nov. 15 when they noticed Rory Clark, 27, and Kimberly Onorato, 28, engaging in sexual activity in the parking lot. The employees then called the police.
"Officers learned that both arrestees were in the vehicle with a six-year old sitting in the back seat," Orange Police said in a statement, according to ctpost. "The child was awake and alert. The female arrestee was partially undressed when officers arrived."
Clark and Onorato reportedly told police that they were "cuddling" rather than having sex, although this was contradicted by several witnesses.
They were both arrested and charged with impairing the morals of a minor. Onorato was also charged with second-degree breach of peace.
Both were released from custody after posting $5,000 bonds.
A relative was given temporary custody of the 6-year-old, while police reported the incident to the Department of Children and Family Services.
Onorato and Clark are scheduled to appear in court on Dec. 8 and Dec. 15 respectively, according to WVIT. It is unknown whether either defendant has secured an attorney.

posts.title: Connecticut couple accused of sex in McDonald's parking lot
posts.text:
Connecticut couple accused of having sex in front of 6-year-old in McDonald’s parking lot Connecticut couple accused of sex in McDonald's parking lot NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, November 22, 2016, 11:49 AM 
A Connecticut couple was arrested on charges for allegedly engaging in sexual activities in a McDonald’s parking lot in front of a 6-year-old child in the back seat, police said. 
Employees at a McDonald’s in Orange spotted the couple — identified as Rory Clark, 27, and Kimberly Onorato, 28 — when leaving their shift at 9:30 p.m. on Nov. 15, police announced Monday. 
Clark and Onorato “appeared to be engaged in sexual activity in the front seats of the car while a small child was seated in the back, watching,” police said in a statement. 
Onorato was partially undressed when officers arrived, authorities allege. Employees at a McDonald’s in Orange (not pictured here) spotted the couple. (Seth Perlman/AP) 
The West Haven couple told police they were only “cuddling” after enjoying a meal at McDonald’s. 
Both Onorato and Clark were arrested and face charges of second-degree breaches of peace and impairing the morals of a minor. Both have court appearances scheduled for December. 
The child was placed in the care of a relative, and the incident was reported to Connecticut’s Department of Children and Family Services. Join the Conversation:

thread.title: A Forlorn Wooden Doll Finds Love at Her Local McDonald's in Brand's Holiday Ad
thread.title_full: A Forlorn Wooden Doll Finds Love at Her Local McDonald's in Brand's Holiday Ad

posts.author: Angela Natividad
posts.title: A Forlorn Wooden Doll Finds Love at Her Local McDonald's in Brand's Holiday Ad
posts.text: A Forlorn Wooden Doll Finds Love at Her Local McDonald's in Brand's Holiday Ad Something you won't find in a Happy Meal By Angela Natividad November 22, 2016, 12:35 PM EST Ah, the holidays! A time for sharing, love and ... McDonald's? In "Juliette the Doll," a charming little ad by Leo Burnett London, a toyshop owner pulls a vintage doll, Juliette, out of a fading box. "Maybe this year," he whispers, setting her in the window. Days pass. People make purchases. Unsurprisingly, our heroine is never one of them. (Who plays with dolls anymore when there are VR Gears to give?) Juliette peers forlonly out the window, offering passersby her best demure poses. Her eyes drift, ever more often, to the cheerful McDonald's across the snowy street, where people seem to be having a grand old time. Dec. 25 finally arrives. When the shopkeeper glances at the window, he finds Juliette has gone. We'll give you one guess where she went. Adweek responsive video player used on /video. There's a lot of love going on at McDonald's, but Juliette finally sets her sights on a shopping bag containing Meteor Mike, a kind of yellow Buzz Lightyear without the goofy helmet (and more hair). As Juliette slips into the bag with her new betrothed, she offers a last wave at her old caretaker. Boy, are those kids in for a surprise when they check their shopping at home! The piece ends with two simple words: "Good times." The work is an expression of McDonald's role as a fueling post for families amid the season's hustle and bustle, and kicks off an eight-week holiday campaign that features a lot more technology than meets the eye here: In addition to all the usual suspects (out-of-home, digital, radio and in-store ads), special tray mats will feature augmented reality technology from Blippar. "Juliette the Doll" is also an innovation lovechild, despite its seemingly modest origins. Its creation included 3-D printing, puppeteering and CGI, with Juliette's face painted on by hand. "McDonald's may not be a brand people immediately associate with Christmas, but it plays a big, perhaps unsung role," explain Leo Burnett creatives Phillip Meyler and Darren Keff. "Millions of people from all walks of life pass through the doors during the festive period, rich or poor, old or young—everyone from an old-fashioned girl from a bygone era, to a futuristic fella from another planet." It's good to know some things will last the ravages of time. And while it isn't exactly heartening to know that our need for fast food is what will last (as opposed to sweet hand-carved toys), the execution is just charming enough to compell us to concede the point. CREDITS Head of Marketing, Brand and Experience, McDonald's UK: Katie Parker Brand Manager, McDonald's UK: Hannah Pain Agency: Leo Burnett, London Creative Director: Pete Heyes, Matt Lee Art Director: Phillip Meyler, Darren Keff Copywriter: Philip Meyler, Darren Keff Account Team: Simon Hewitt, Sam Houlston, Ailsa McQuaid and Gracie Smith Agency Producer: Lou Pegg

× Police: Couple arrested for having sex in front seat while 6-year-old was in back 
ORANGE–Two McDonald’s employees who were leaving work last Tuesday probably didn’t expect to see two of their customers in the parking lot partially naked. But they say they did. 
On November 15 around 9:30 p.m. two people were leaving work after their shifts at the fast food restaurant located at 57 Boston Post Road in Orange when they noticed a parked car with two people inside. The employees called police to say it appeared the pair were having sex, and that a small child was in the back watching. 
When police arrived they found a woman partially naked in the front seat with a man, and a 6-year-old in the back seat who was alert and awake. 
The couple said they were “cuddling” after eating at McDonald’s. 
Police arrested Rory Clark, 27, of West Haven, and Kimberly Onorato, 28, of Bristol. Both were charged with second-degree breach of peace and impairing the morals of a minor , and both were released on $5,000 bond. 41.278640 -72.987845

posts.author: WWWNews (noreply@blogger.com)
posts.title: 21-year-old man dies after waving gun around and accidentally shooting himself in the head
posts.text:
Kavon Antoan Cooper  By: Wayne Morin 

(Scroll down for video) Police were called to a McDonald’s parking lot after a man accidentally shot himself while waving a gun.

21-year-old Kavon Antoan Cooper of Virginia, shot himself in the head after waving the gun around while sitting in a car, state police said.

Police said that Cooper was riding in a car with two other men when he accidentally shot himself at 2:45 a.m. on Sunday, according to police.

The driver immediately took an exit off the I-85 and pulled into a McDonald's parking lot, where he called police.

When rescue workers arrived, they were unable to save Cooper, and he was pronounced dead.

The driver and the other passenger were not injured during the shooting.

posts.author: The Associated Press
posts.title: Police: Couple had sex in McDonald’s lot in front of 6-year-old boy
posts.text:
ORANGE, Conn. (AP) – A Connecticut couple is facing charges after police say they engaged in sexual activity in a parked car with a 6-year-old boy in the back seat.
Police in Orange say two McDonald’s employees were leaving the restaurant on Nov. 15 when they spotted two people engaged in sexual activity in the front seats of a car. They say the child was in the back seat, awake and alert.
Police say they arrived to find 28-year-old Kimberly Onorato partially undressed. Police say Onorato and 27-year-old Rory Clark stated they had only been cuddling.
Clark and Onorato are both charged with impairing morals of a minor and breach of peace. Online court records don’t list lawyers for the pair.
The child was turned over to a relative. Police also contacted child welfare authorities.

thread.title: Taste Test: Coffee purists not keen on McDonald's Peppermint Mocha
thread.title_full: Taste Test: Coffee purists not keen on McDonald's Peppermint Mocha

posts.author: Laura Kessel   Repository engagement editor
posts.title: Taste Test: Coffee purists not keen on McDonald's Peppermint Mocha
posts.text:
Taste Test: Coffee purists not keen on McDonald's Peppermint Mocha Tuesday Nov 22, 2016 at 2:00 PM COMMENTARY: Repository testers thought this holiday concoction was just OK. Be careful of the high calorie count. By Laura Kessel Repository engagement editor 
I saw my first Christmas commercial during the World Series, so it's not inconceivable that the early fall abundance of pumpkin flavor is getting a challenge from its winter successor — peppermint. 
In fact, about two weeks ago, while driving south down Market Avenue to work, I passed McDonald's and noted its sign listed Peppermint Mocha was now available. 
*PERK* 
I'm a mint nut, whether it's the spearmint gum I'm chewing as I write this or the mint chocolate chip ice cream I order at Handel's, or the peppermint tea bags I drop all winter during the work day. 
I'm less a mocha fan, though. The coffee drink amped by chocolate flavor has a tendency to get a bit thick for my idea of an ideal cup of coffee. I treat mochas as a dessert, or even (probably bogusly) an option when I don't want quite THAT much caffeine. 
So, I met the McDonald's menu sign with a chuckle Thursday morning when I noticed it listed its mocha with Peppermint Hot Chocolate. Aren't they basically the same thing? To my mouth, they usually are. 
But, we had decided on the mocha, so mocha it was. 
I erred when I ordered, not realizing I could have chosen skim milk over the whole milk that was served up. Thus, it became a little more thick and creamy than I'd probably normally drink. 
Signs make it clear that this drink is a calorie hog. You're looking at as many calories as some of the snack bars we've tried recently, in a beverage. There's some protein to help, though. Mocha offers 8 grams, hot chocolate has 9. 
As I drove to the office with four mochas sitting next to me in the front seat, I was happily breathing in plenty of mint aroma. When it came time to drink it, though, the chocolate overwhelmed the mint. The farther I went into the drink, the more I found, though. So, when I swished it around, it improved the mix some, but still not enough to bring that mint to the forefront. 
I'll say that a small is plenty. (They offer small, medium and large.) There's enough flavor, whether you find the mint or just enjoy the chocolate, in the small. You'll also be packing on more calories and fat as you increase that serving size, don't forget. Not sure it's really worth that expense, particularly in a season that's already bursting with flavor. 
Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed this drink. I'll likely order a few more as we move through November and more toward Christmastime. Most coffee places have launched or will soon debut their versions of this drink. I'll opt for the skim milk next time, though. 
Here's what our other tasters thought: 
Denise Sautters: 
As coffee goes, not bad. 
To be perfectly honest, I am more of a hot tea drinker as long as it is flavored, but this Peppermint Mocha, albeit not that peppermint tasting, is palatable. 
But, then it isn't bitter like black coffee either. It could easily use a peppermint stick to add to the flavor. Is it worth the calories it carries? Not when I can have a cup of unsweetened flavored tea for zero calories. However, I would buy this again because somedays, you just need that sweet pick-me-up and the caffeine it offers to get going. 
Dan Kane: 
My coffee preference is boringly simple. I like my coffee with cream, no sugar. Not into pumpkin spice lattes, banana cream pie lattes, hot fudge sundae lattes, any of that. So my enthusiasm for this chocolate mint coffee from McDonald's is very low. Frankly, it tastes a bit like green Lavoris mouthwash. 
Gary Brown: 
It's very minty. It helps to like candy canes if you drink McDonald's seasonal Peppermint Mocha flavor coffee. Fortunately, I do. In small sizes. 
It's that time of year. We're phasing out the Halloween and Thanksgiving java flavors (think pumpkin spice) and moving on into the Christmas coffee concoctions. 
I'm a fan of this, and McDonald's Peppermint Mocha fits into my lifestyle now and then. I could sip a cup of this at night, after dinner, perhaps. Not in the morning. My mornings are for hot, black, unsweetened and eye-opening coffee. 
Peppermint Mocha is creamed and sweet and mint-filled. So, maybe if allowed to cool to warm, it's kind of tasty for drawing a day to a close ... if you can forget you just consumed a cupful of caffeine so you can get to sleep. 
I like such flavored coffees, in moderation and for short duration, so McDonald's Peppermint Mocha seems to me to be not bad for what it does — gets us in the mood for the holiday season. Still, holidays end, and we move on to the next flavor. There's a reason we don't eat ribbon candy all year long. About Us

thread.title: Market rally can continue through 2017, strategist says
thread.title_full: Market rally can continue through 2017, strategist says

posts.author: Michelle Fox
posts.title: Market rally can continue through 2017, strategist says
posts.text:
show chapters 
McDonald: Rally will continue through 2017
Jim McDonald, Northern Trust, and Tilman Fertitta, Landry's Restaurants Chairman & CEO, weigh in on the Trump rally, and whether it will last.
McDonald: Rally will continue through 2017      1 Hour Ago | 02:45 Don't expect the market rally to end anytime soon, strategist Jim McDonald told CNBC on Tuesday. 

Stocks hit all-time highs in intraday trading Tuesday, with the Dow Jones industrial average breaking above 19,000 for the first time. 
The markets have been moving higher since the Republican sweep on Election Day , which landed Donald Trump in the White House and the GOP keeping control of both houses of Congress. However, McDonald told " Power Lunch " he believes the recent run is more than just a postelection bounce. 
"Breaking up legislative logjam will be helpful but the global economy has actually been gaining momentum since August. We think this momentum will continue into next year," said McDonald, who oversees $946 billion as chief investment strategist for Northern Trust. 
"As long as rates don't jump too high, which we don't think they will, we think the rally can continue through 2017," he added. 
One of his favorite sectors is financials , which he said will benefit from higher interest rates and the deregulation expected from the Trump administration.

thread.title: WSU-branded fries are on the menu at McDonald’s
thread.title_full: WSU-branded fries are on the menu at McDonald’s

posts.author:
Craig Sailor 
csailor@thenewstribune.com
posts.title: WSU-branded fries are on the menu at McDonald’s
posts.text:
“Would you like fries with that?” 
For Washington State University potato researchers the answer is always yes. 
Nobody in the world buys more potatoes than McDonald’s. 
So it’s a big deal when the fast-food giant deems a new spud worthy of a ketchup dunking in its 36,615 restaurants worldwide. 
Naturally, the company is picky about its potatoes. 
In September, Ronald and friends added two new russet potato varieties developed in part by WSU professors in Pullman. 
Potato researchers Rick Knowles and Mark Pavek are the french-fried masterminds behind the spuds. 
“McDonald’s has expert tasters, kind of like with fine wine,” said horticulture professor Knowles. “Their gold standard potato for french fries is a Russet Burbank, which makes a great fry but is really inefficient from a production standpoint.” 
“Burbank has disease issues and requires high soil fertility and water,” said Pavek, an associate professor. “And it has a lower yield of the highest-grade tubers because it’s susceptible to so many stress-related disorders.” 
If this is about potatoes, then naturally Idaho is involved. 
The WSU researchers worked with colleagues from the University of Idaho, U.S. Department of Agriculture and Oregon State University on the new potatoes. 
The Clearwater Russet and Blazer Russet aren’t the first WSU-developed potatoes to be accepted by McDonald’s. Four out of the seven varieties the company uses were developed by the consortium also known as the Northwest Potato Variety Development Program. 
The Clearwater Russet comes with a bonus: 33 percent more protein than Burbank. 
“Potatoes are already very nutritious, with high levels of vitamin C and a good balance of amino acids,” Pavek said. “But Clearwater Russets are even better. It’s a nice little add-on to an already great potato.” 
Seed production for the two new russets has been ramped up. That’s good for the program as it earns royalties on varieties it develops.

ORANGE, Conn. – Two McDonald’s employees called police after walking out of the restaurant to find a couple in a parked car “engaged in sexual activity,” police said Monday. 
The workers had just finished their shifts at the Orange, Connecticut, McDonald’s around 9:30 p.m. on November 15, when they noticed the vehicle. One of the employees told a 911 operator it appeared the pair were having sex, and that “a small child was seated in the back, watching,” according to police. Kimberly Onorato, 28, and Rory Clark, 27, allegedly told police that they were “cuddling” after two McDonald’s employees called 911 to report two people engaged in sexual activity in the parking lot. (Town of Orange Police Department) 
When police arrived, they found a woman partially-naked in the front seat with a man, and a 6-year-old in the back seat who was “alert and awake,” WTIC reported. 
The couple said they were “cuddling” after eating at McDonald’s, according to police. 
Officers arrested Rory Clark, 27, of West Haven, and Kimberly Onorato, 28, of Bristol. Both were charged with second-degree breach of peace and impairing the morals of a minor. 
They were both released on $5,000 bond.

thread.title: Starbucks Vs. McDonald's
thread.title_full: Starbucks Vs. McDonald's

posts.title: Starbucks Vs. McDonald's
posts.text:
The two companies have grown into giants. 
McDonald's is an older and more mature company. 
Does McDonald's have any wisdom to pass down to Starbucks, and Starbucks investors? There are obvious similarities between McDonald's ( MCD ) and Starbucks ( SBUX ). The global fast serve giants are ubiquitous from U.S. to China and nearly everywhere in between. I've seen some articles comparing the two companies in terms of valuation metrics, dividends and potential growth. Which is the better buy? You can find out here and here if interested. However, I want to take a different perspective. How about comparing the companies in terms of how they have grown globally and how the share price has grown? The reason for this angle is simple. McDonald's is a much older company. It passed the 30,000 locations milestone over ten years ago. At that point in time Starbucks still had under 10,000 locations, but it is catching up quickly, and currently has 23,768 stores. Will the company, and the stock, experience similar growing pains? Starbucks' current store count equates to McDonald's in 1997 when it passed 23,000 total stores and was opening 2000 locations a year ( source ). Starbucks is currently growing at almost the same rate and is expected to open 1,800 locations this year. Eventually the growth will slow as global locations become saturated, as shown here by McDonald's: Click to enlarge Starbucks will at some point catch up and its growth will slow in a similar way. We don't know if it will be at 30,000 locations or 28,000, but it is inevitable. What might this mean for the stock price? The Crashing Giants When McDonald's growth began to slow, it's share price wavered too. From the peak of 1999 to the lows of 2003 the stock fell over 75%. You may say it was due to the stock market crash in the same period, but why then did the stock not crash again during the 2007-2009 decline? The S&P500 fell more during this period, yet McDonald's traded sideways and even made a new all time high in August 2008. We cannot make simple cause and effect formulas for stocks. McDonald's fell 75% between 1999-2003 due to a complex mixture of catalysts which all interacted with positioning in the stock. Slowing growth was just one factor. This is also the case for Starbucks. During the same stock market crashes it had the exact opposite reactions to McDonald's. During 1999-2001 it traded sideways and in 2006-2008 it fell over 80%. Lack of growth was not the reason for the 2006 peak: source: knoema.com The number of stores plateau'd in 2009-2011, but this was after the stock dropped 82%. It would be nice to draw a concise conclusion and comparison from all this data, but I simply can't. If Starbucks hadn't corrected so much in 2006-2008 I'd say a crash was almost certainly due in the next few years based on the McDonald's lead. As it is, both stocks have crashed and this gives them very similar stock cycles even when the growth in the companies are slightly different. Stock Cycles The below chart shows each stock side by side on the time axis. McDonald's IPO'd much before Starbucks. It's largest rally (in percentage points) was into the 1999 peak, after which its main correction began. Starbucks' main growth was from its IPO in 1992 to a 2006 peak when its major decline began. If you move the stocks so that their cycles match, this is what you get: Click to enlarge The stocks have gone through the same growth phase, the same corrective cycle, and the same recovery. It also suggests Starbucks has a lag of a few years and still has some catching up to do. This is supported by the idea that Starbucks is still growing its locations and its share price has the potential to grow further and faster. If we take the analogy further and we equate the Starbucks current total stores and growth to McDonald's in 1997, is the price action similar? The year long consolidation does have similarities, and it's worth keeping an eye on the above chart as a guide as it suggests something very similar to the first comparison. i.e. price is likely to make another high, but the general direction is sideways for another year before a final larger rally. This is helpful to me (I am long). I have always known Starbucks' growth will slow, but I haven't really been able to imagine how this will be reflected in the share price. I'm not sure if we get a very close repeat to the two charts above, but I know where price should be heading. As we have seen, McDonald's is more advanced in its cycle, but it is also repeating the same period as Starbucks is in the above chart. This is because markets and stock cycles are fractal. McDonald's is repeating itself and is rallying into a medium term top just like it did in 1999. Click to enlarge The size and type of the decline is unlikely to be similar to 1999-2003, but I do expect a long pause and sideways consolidation when the current cycle is complete. Conclusions There are as many differences as similarities between McDonald's and Starbucks. Please don't point out in the comments section that one sells hamburgers and one sells coffee. I am looking for similarities in growth and in stock cycles. McDonald's has the lead in both and it can act as a guide for investors. Disclosure: I am/we are long SBUX. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article. About this article: Expand Author payment: $35 + $0.01/page view. Authors of PRO articles receive a minimum guaranteed payment of $150-500. Become a contributor »

thread.section_title: This Canadian Airline Will Be the First to Serve McDonald’s Coffee – Fortune
thread.title: This Canadian Airline Will Be the First to Serve McDonald’s Coffee
thread.title_full: This Canadian Airline Will Be the First to Serve McDonald’s Coffee

posts.author: Madeline Farber
posts.title: This Canadian Airline Will Be the First to Serve McDonald’s Coffee
posts.text:
After an ongoing coffee war, McDonald’s Canada has finally won: WestJet, a Calgary, Canada-based airline, will start serving the chain’s coffee on its flights.
“The collaboration between our two caring brands is a perfect pairing, as McCaf?’s values are reflected in WestJet’s commitment to offer an unmatched guest experience,” said Gregg Saretsky, WestJet’s CEO, in a statement released Monday. WestJet is the first airline in the world to offer McCaf? on board, McDonald’s Canada’s communications manager Adam Grachnik confirmed to Fortune. 
Both Starbucks sbux and Tim Hortons thi also bid to supply WestJet flyers with their caffeine buzz. But McDonald’s Canada was mainly chosen based on price and other factors, Toronto Star notes, including a previous partnership with WestJet in children's charities.
According to the press release, those on WestJet flights from Toronto to Calgary will be offered the McCaf? Premium Roast coffee today. The airline will expand the service across its entire fleet, including its regional airline, WestJet Encore, by Dec. 1.
 
Since a person’s taste buds are less sensitive at flying altitude, the airline's McCafe coffee will be “slightly different” than the coffee served in McDonald's restaurants, according to the Star-- a darker roast of beans and a hotter water temperature will be used in-flight to achieve a similar taste.
Two other Canadian airlines serve big-name coffee on their aircraft, the Star reports: Air Canada serves Second Cup coffee on its flights, and Porter Airlines serves Starbucks.
We’ve always believed that the sky is the limit for McCaf?,” McDonald’s Canada President John Betts said in the press release, “and today this officially rings true.”

thread.title: McDonald’s franchise pays $103,000 to employee fired for being HIV-positive
thread.title_full: McDonald’s franchise pays $103,000 to employee fired for being HIV-positive

posts.author: Jeff Taylor
posts.title: McDonald’s franchise pays $103,000 to employee fired for being HIV-positive
posts.text:
NNECAPA on Flickr (CC 2.0) 
Owners of an Arkansas McDonald’s franchise paid $103,000 to settle a complaint brought by an employee fired for being HIV -positive. 
The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) report that after initially attempting to reach a voluntary pre-litigation settlement through its conciliation process, they filed the lawsuit in July on behalf of the unnamed employee. 
According to the complaint, the unnamed employee of a Bentonville, Arkansas was fired in February 2015 when he revealed to a coworker he was interested in dating that he was HIV-positive. The alleged conduct is in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). 
“People with HIV face enough obstacles in their lives,” said Katharine Kores, an EEOC district director, said in a statement at the time of the lawsuit’s announcement. “The ability to work in an environment free of discrimination should not be one of them.” 
The order of payment came down on Nov. 10, and the company will also be conducting disability training for its managers and revise their policy requiring mandatory disclosure of prescription medications. 
“EEOC remains committed to protecting employees from disability discrimination on the job,” said Faye A. Williams, regional attorney of the agency’s Memphis District Office, which has jurisdiction over Arkansas, Tennessee and portions of Mississippi . “EEOC commends the companies for working with us to quickly resolve this matter prior to trial.”

thread.title: McDonald’s franchisee files for bankruptcy
thread.title_full: McDonald’s franchisee files for bankruptcy

posts.title: McDonald’s franchisee files for bankruptcy
posts.text:
Home > Finance > McDonald’s franchisee files for bankruptcy McDonald’s franchisee files for bankruptcy Sales losses and competition push Brown Customer Delight Group Inc. to seek debt protection Comments 0 Advertisement 
A six-unit McDonald’s Corp. franchisee based in Iowa filed for bankruptcy this week, citing increasing competition from other chains — and from McDonald’s itself. 
The company, Brown Customer Delight Group Inc., or BCDG, at one time had 10 locations in the Des Moines area, but has since sold four units amid heavy debt and financial losses. 
In a filing this week, the operator said that “increased competition from other fast-food restaurants” led to decreased sales in recent years. BCDG also said that McDonald’s construction of new restaurants stole sales from its locations. 
BCDG’s restaurants generated sales of $7.6 million through August, but according to bankruptcy documents, sales fell by $4.5 million in 2015, when the company recorded a loss of just under $900,000. The company reported $6.7 million in assets and $15.6 million in liabilities, according to filings. BCDG’s largest secured creditor is Citizens Bank of Boston, to which it owes $6.1 million. 
Bankruptcies among McDonald’s franchisees are relatively uncommon, in part because the company’s franchise agreement strongly discourages such actions, said Richard Adams, a former McDonald’s operator turned consultant. Struggling operators typically sell their restaurants first, he said. 
“If a franchisee is failing, it’s usually better to sell to another franchisee and pray that after debts are paid the franchisee walks away with at least some proceeds,” Adams said. “Filing for bankruptcy hands over all control to the courts and the company.” 
In this instance, the operator owned a trio of units in suburban Minneapolis for a decade before selling those locations to buy 10 units in Central Iowa in 2011. As part of the deal, BCDG was required to remodel all of the locations, according to BCDG president Larry Brown in a bankruptcy document. 
In the filing, Brown said that the restaurants did not meet profit expectations, requiring the company to borrow more money to cover the cost of the remodels, which were completed in 2012. 
According to the filing, in 2013 McDonald’s said it planned to open a location between two of BCDG’s units in Ankeny, Iowa. Brown said he opted to pay $2 million to buy the location, which was expected to generate $2.7 million in revenue. The location fell $1 million short of that projection, and, he wrote, the two existing locations’ sales declined after the restaurant opened. 
BCDG ultimately decided to sell five restaurants in a bid to reduce debt, but the sale of the restaurants didn’t cover the debt. 
The company did cut some costs this year, but investments required as part of McDonald’s all-day breakfast promotion offset those savings, the company said in a court document. 
BCDG borrowed money to cover its shortfalls this year and asked a consultant for help in analyzing the operations to find solutions to its problems. The consultant was not able to recommend any solutions. 
In August, McDonald’s moved to terminate BCDG’s franchise agreement, and the company filed for bankruptcy protection.

posts.author: Shawn Rice
posts.title: The Voice Live Playoffs: America Saves Sundance Head And We McDonald
posts.text:
Carson Daly announced that Sundance Head and We McDonald who are saved for another round on The Voice. The live playoffs are upon us as the top 11 hopeful artists compete to come out on top on The Voice. Sundance Head, Austin Allsup and Courtney Harrell performed with Blake Shelton.
Sundance’s father, Roy Head, was in the band The Traits, best known for their 1965 hit, “Treat Her Right.” When Sundance was 9, his older brother passed away in a tragic car accident, and his dad began to slow down his music career. At age 20, Sundance had the opportunity to record with ZZ Top through a connection from his dad, but started to play music professionally 13 years later. He put a band together called Sundance Head that plays all over Texas. His wife of nine years is his manager.
The name Wé is Kenyan for “diligence,” which is something that Wé has had her entire life. Her father helped her get into vocal lessons at the Harlem School of the Arts, which she still attends after school and on weekends. Wé has performed at Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall and, most recently, at the Apollo Theater. Although Wé has always found her place with music, she struggled to fit in at school. Kids teased her for her high-pitched voice and thick glasses, but she stuck it out and slowly things got better. Now she embraces her differences and is hoping her uniqueness will help her stand out on The Voice.
In the final live-performance phase of the competition, the Top 12 artists compete each week against each other during a live broadcast. The television audience votes to save their favorite artists. The three artists with the lowest number of votes are eligible for the “Instant Save.” These artists each perform a new song that represents why they should earn the save. Then, America has the opportunity to save their favorite performer by tweeting #VoiceSave along with the artist’s name. The singers with the lowest number of votes are sent home each week. In the end, one is named “The Voice” and receives the grand prize of a recording contract.

From left, Christian Cuevas, Alicia Keys and We McDonald sing "People Get Ready" on NBC's "The Voice" Tuesday night. Cuevas will compete on next Monday's Top 10 competition on Season 11 of the show. NBC 
Christian Cuevas sings on Tuesday night's episode of NBC's "The Voice." 
Christian Cuevas, an Orlando, Florida, singer whose brother is a local Realtor, garnered enough audience votes to send him to next week's top-10 competition on the TV singing contest “The Voice.” 
After singing Curtis Mayfield’s soul classic, “People Get Ready,” with his celebrity coach, Alicia Keys, and teammate We McDonald on Tuesday night's episode, Cuevas learned that the audience’s votes had saved him to compete next week. 
The newly engaged Cuevas, whose brother is Handy Cuevas of Lancaster, sang Toto’s “Rosanna” on Monday’s episode of the NBC show. 
The Cuevas brothers’ late father, Julio, was a Puerto Rican singer and recording artist.

thread.title_full: Big and Small Versions of McDonald's Big Mac Coming in 2017

posts.author: Q (noreply@blogger.com)
posts.title: Big and Small Versions of McDonald's Big Mac Coming in 2017
posts.text:
If you've been wishing the Big Mac were just a little bigger... or smaller, McDonald's will be bringing both a larger and smaller version of their iconic burger nationwide for a limited time in early 2017.

The bigger of the two, the new Grand Mac , boasts two larger beef patties weighing a third of a pound together. It also comes with a larger sesame seed bun along with the expected special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles, and onions.

The new Mac Jr. features the same special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles, and onions but only sports a single beef patty, albeit a slightly larger one, and forgoes the middle bun.

If you're a Big Mac fan that lives in Florida or the Pittsburgh area, you'll be happy to know that the two new burgers are available there now ahead of the nationwide launch.

Photo via McDonald's. Read more at Brand Eating !

thread.title: This McD's Franchise Owner Wasn't Lovin' It (MCD)
thread.title_full: This McD's Franchise Owner Wasn't Lovin' It (MCD)

posts.author: Dan Moskowitz
posts.title: This McD's Franchise Owner Wasn't Lovin' It (MCD)
posts.text:
Is This a Warning Sign for McDonald’s? (MCD) By Dan Moskowitz | November 22, 2016 — 11:26 AM EST 
It’s not often that McDonald's Corp. ( MCD ) and bankruptcy are found in the same sentence, but that’s the case here. As of December 31, 2015, McDonald's operated 36,525 restaurants, including 30,081 franchised restaurants. By having so many franchisee locations, McDonald’s saves significantly on costs, but this also runs the risk of poor franchisee management, which can then lead to a tarnished brand image. This isn’t to say that was the case with Brown Customer Delight Group Inc., but it’s a possibility. 
Brown Customer Delight Group is owned by Larry and Brenda Brown, who have filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The Browns own five stores in Des Moines and one in Indianapolis. They cited mounting debt and increased competition from company-owned McDonald’s. They specifically mentioned that McDonald’s opened 2-3 company-owned stores in the metro area, which led to reduced sales. Currently, the Brown Customer Delight Group has $6.7 million in assets versus $15.6 million in liabilities . According to court documents, the six stores as a whole lost $4.5 million in 2015. 
In addition to increased competition from McDonald’s company-owned stores, the Browns stated that they needed technological upgrades in order to support all-day breakfast, which was not received. One way or another, something went wrong at the higher levels at McDonald’s management. Either they didn’t assist the franchisee to help the franchisee succeed or they disregarded the franchisee’s business by opening nearby locations, which thereby led to cannibalization . Another possibility is that McDonald’s didn’t keep a close eye on its franchisee, which is important because of the brand’s image. Either way, there was a failure somewhere along the line. 
This news isn’t immediately bearish for MCD, but with increased competition and the brand’s reputation for dirty restaurants and poor customer service, it’s a small step backward, and it could indicate that quality control is lacking. 
MCD has depreciated 4.83% over the past 12 months and currently offers a dividend yield of 3.18%.

thread.title: Couple accused of having sex in McDonald’s parking lot as 6-year-old watched | fox5sandiego.com

posts.title: Couple accused of having sex in McDonald’s parking lot as 6-year-old watched | fox5sandiego.com
posts.text:
Email 
ORANGE, Conn. – Two McDonald’s employees called police after walking out of the restaurant to find a couple in a parked car “engaged in sexual activity,” police said Monday. 
The workers had just finished their shifts at the Orange, Connecticut, McDonald’s around 9:30 p.m. on November 15, when they noticed the vehicle. One of the employees told a 911 operator it appeared the pair were having sex, and that “a small child was seated in the back, watching,” according to police. Kimberly Onorato, 28, and Rory Clark, 27, allegedly told police that they were “cuddling” after two McDonald’s employees called 911 to report two people engaged in sexual activity in the parking lot. (Town of Orange Police Department) 
When police arrived, they found a woman partially-naked in the front seat with a man, and a 6-year-old in the back seat who was “alert and awake,” WTIC reported. 
The couple said they were “cuddling”after eating at McDonald’s, according to police. 
Officers arrested Rory Clark, 27, of West Haven, and Kimberly Onorato, 28, of Bristol. Both were charged with second-degree breach of peace and impairing the morals of a minor. 
They were both released on $5,000 bond.

thread.title: McDonald's: WestJet First to Serve McCafe Premium Roast
thread.title_full: McDonald's: WestJet First to Serve McCafe Premium Roast

posts.author: Madeline Farber
posts.title: McDonald's: WestJet First to Serve McCafe Premium Roast
posts.text:
After an ongoing coffee war, McDonald’s Canada has finally won: WestJet, a Calgary, Canada-based airline, will start serving the chain’s coffee on its flights.
“The collaboration between our two caring brands is a perfect pairing, as McCafé’s values are reflected in WestJet’s commitment to offer an unmatched guest experience,” said Gregg Saretsky, WestJet’s CEO, in a statement released Monday. WestJet is the first airline in the world to offer McCafé on board, McDonald’s Canada’s communications manager Adam Grachnik confirmed to Fortune.
Both Starbucks sbux and Tim Hortons thi also bid to supply WestJet flyers with their caffeine buzz. But McDonald’s Canada was mainly chosen based on price and other factors, Toronto Star notes, including a previous partnership with WestJet in children’s charities.
According to the press release, those on WestJet flights from Toronto to Calgary will be offered the McCafé Premium Roast coffee today. The airline will expand the service across its entire fleet, including its regional airline, WestJet Encore, by Dec. 1.
Since a person’s taste buds are less sensitive at flying altitude, the airline’s McCafe coffee will be “slightly different” than the coffee served in McDonald’s restaurants, according to the Star— a darker roast of beans and a hotter water temperature will be used in-flight to achieve a similar taste.
Two other Canadian airlines serve big-name coffee on their aircraft, the Star reports: Air Canada serves Second Cup coffee on its flights, and Porter Airlines serves Starbucks.
“We’ve always believed that the sky is the limit for McCafé,” McDonald’s Canada President John Betts said in the press release, “and today this officially rings true.”

posts.text: A Vintage Doll Finds Love In McDonald’s ‘Toy Story’-esque Christmas Ad By Chloe Pek   The festive season can trigger feelings of loneliness, especially when you are a vintage wooden doll stuck in the window of a toy shop. thread.title: Couple Arrested for Sex in McDonald's Parking Lot—in Front of a 6-Year-Old Boy | PJ Media

posts.author: Paula Bolyard
posts.title: Couple Arrested for Sex in McDonald's Parking Lot—in Front of a 6-Year-Old Boy | PJ Media
posts.text:
This gives new meaning to the term "McDonald's Playland."
A Connecticut couple was arrested last week after they were caught having sex in a McDonald's parking lot—in front of a 6-year old boy.
Police in Orange, Conn., said that two McDonald's employees were on their way out of the restaurant on November 15 when they discovered a couple "engaged in sexual activity in a parked car," according to an Associated Press report . The employees said that a 6-year-old boy, who was "alert and awake," was right behind the couple in the back seat. The report did not note whether the child was the couple's son.
'Demon Rat' Day Care Van Terrifies Parents and Children
When police arrived, they found Kimberly Oranato, 28, partially undressed in the vehicle, along with 27-year-old Rory Clark. According to police, the couple claims they had only been cuddling.
Both Clark and Oronato were charged with impairing the morals of a minor (for, you know, cuddling) and breach of peace (that must have been some enthusiastic cuddling).
Police notified child welfare authorities of the "cuddling" incident and turned the child over to a relative.
The report does not mention whether anyone else at McDonald's got a side of morals-corrupting cuddling with their Big Macs that night.
Apparently, it's not completely unheard of for couples to get their cuddle on at McDonald's. In 2013 a couple was kicked out of a UK McDonald's for having sex on the floor ... in the bathroom of the restaurant. In 2014 two women were attacked after they were discovered having sex in an Upper Darby, Penn., McDonald's ... again, in the bathroom.
But it's not just recreational sex that parents need to be concerned about. Last year a homeless man was charged with capital sexual battery in Jacksonville, Fla. after his horrific attack on a 6-year-old boy.
Keep your kiddos close, parents.

(Town of Orange Police Department via AP) less This undated handout photo provided by the Town of Orange Police Department in Connecticut shows Rory Clark. Clark was charged with a felony count of impairing morals of a minor and misdemeanor breach of peace ... more Photo: Uncredited, AP Police: Couple had sex in McDonald's lot in front of boy, 6 1 / 2 Back to Gallery 
ORANGE, Conn. (AP) — A Connecticut couple is facing charges after police say they engaged in sexual activity in a parked car with a 6-year-old boy in the back seat. 
Police in Orange say two McDonald's employees were leaving the restaurant on Nov. 15 when they spotted two people engaged in sexual activity in the front seats of a car. They say the child was in the back seat, awake and alert. 
Police say they arrived to find 28-year-old Kimberly Onorato partially undressed. Police say Onorato and 27-year-old Rory Clark stated they had only been cuddling. 
Clark and Onorato are both charged with impairing morals of a minor and breach of peace. Online court records don't list lawyers for the pair. 
The child was turned over to a relative. Police also contacted child welfare authorities. posts.text:
You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters More on this Concert ticket information 
After Hurricane Matthew, many in NC were left homeless, stranded and unsure of their next steps. In the spirit of Giving Tuesday, local McDonald’s in Central N.C. along with Duke Energy and Ticketmaster have partnered with Tim Stevens, founder of Garner’s own Broadway Voices, to host “Three Phantoms in Concert.” 
This two-hour concert will feature music from popular Broadways shows, including Phantom of the Opera, Les Miserables, Guys and Dolls and more. 
One hundred percent of the proceeds from ticket sales will be donated to relief and recovery efforts in North Carolina through the N.C. Baptists on Mission who rebuild homes at no cost to families in crisis. The organization has served more than 300,000 meals and has completed tear outs and mud outs of hundreds of homes in the last two weeks since the hurricane. 
Show Details: 
Time: 7:30 PM 
Location: Duke Energy Center for the Performing Arts, 2 E. South St., Raleigh, NC 27601 
“We are humbled to be a part of this effort and look forward to supporting all of the families in our state recovering from the hurricane,” said local McDonald’s Owner/Operator Doris Huebner. 
Ticket prices start at $20 and can be purchased at Ticketmaster , DukeEnergyCenterRaleigh.com or at the Duke Energy Center Box Office. Giveaway 
To enter to win 2 tickets to this impressive concert on Tuesday, November 29 along with McDonald’s coupon cards for free McCafe beverages, please share an act of kindness (or an “act of lovin’” as McDonald's like to day) that you’ve witnessed or have taken part in. It could concern Hurricane Matthew or just have happened in everyday life. McDonald’s wants to continue to spread the lovin’! 
You can make a comment by clicking the Comment Bubble at the top right of this post. If this is your first comment on this blog, you will need to sign up one time and then you can make comments at any time. 
You have until Tuesday, 11/22 at 11:59 pm to enter. The winning name will be posted Wednesday here on the blog. One entry per person.

thread.title_full: McDonald, Lelia Ward

posts.title: McDonald, Lelia Ward
posts.text: Lelia Ward McDonald 1918 - 2016 Obituary Condolences HAMPTON - Lelia Ward McDonald, 98, passed away Saturday, November 19, 2016 in Hampton, Virginia. She was a native of Northampton County, Virginia, raised in Newport News, and a Hampton resident for most of her life. She was a member of Aldersgate United Methodist Church in Hampton. She enjoyed playing bridge, listening to music, and traveling. Lelia was employed at Silverman Furs in Newport News for 35 years. She is survived by a daughter, Constance M. Smith of Hampton; a son, John H. McDonald (Rosanna) of Wilson, NC; two grandchildren, Ralph Smith (Debbie) and Elizabeth Mainwaring (Tom); and four great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Saturday, November 26, 2016 at 11:00 AM at Aldersgate United Methodist Church, 151 Wythe Pkwy., Hampton, VA 23661. Memorial donations may be made to Aldersgate United Methodist Church at the address listed above. Online condolences may be sent to the family at www.doughtyfuneralhome.com Arrangements were made by Doughty Funeral Home in Exmore, Virginia.

thread.title: Child watches as two adults have sex outside McDonald’s
thread.title_full: Child watches as two adults have sex outside McDonald’s

posts.author: WWWNews (noreply@blogger.com)
posts.title: Child watches as two adults have sex outside McDonald’s
posts.text:
Feng Qian   By: Kimberly Onorato and Rory Clark 

Police were called after people spotted a couple in Connecticut, having sex outside of a McDonald’s.

Kimberly Onorato, 28, and Rory Clark, 27, were arrested after being accused of having sex in a vehicle that was in a McDonald's parking lot with a child in the back seat.

Police in Orange, said the incident occurred around 9:30 p.m., at the fast food restaurant on Boston Post Road.

“McDonald's employees who were leaving work after their shift ended at 9:30 p.m., noticed a car parked outside the store with two people inside,” Orange police said on Facebook. 

“The two adults appeared to be involved in sexual activities in the front seats of the car while a 6-year-old child was sitting in the back, watching. The child was sitting in the backseat, and was awake and alert,” police said.

The woman was partially undressed when officers arrived. The couple told police that they had only been “cuddling” after enjoying a meal at McDonald’s. However, police said that witnesses declared otherwise.

Onorato and Clark were arrested. The child was placed in the custody of a family member. The incident was also reported to the Department of Children and Family Services.

Clark was charged with impairing the morals of a minor. He was released after posting a $5,000 bond.

Onorato was charged with impairing the morals of a minor and second-degree breach of peace. She also posted a $5,000 bond.

thread.title: Customer among those helping TX McDonald's employee raise money for cancer treatment
thread.title_full: Customer among those helping TX McDonald's employee raise money for cancer treatment

posts.author: Wes Anderson
posts.title: Customer among those helping TX McDonald's employee raise money for cancer treatment
posts.text: 11/23/16 08:05 am EST . FRISCO, Tx. (KXAS-TV) A McDonald's employee in Frisco has been a familiar face at the drive-thru for 14 years. John Marsh is the kind of worker who remembers everyone. "If I see you one or two times, I'm going to remember you," said Marsh. "When you hit that corner, I'll be smiling. I'm going to know you. I may not know your name, but I'm going to know you." Marsh, 62, is college-educated with degrees in business management and criminal justice, and he has a master's degree in gerontology. Marsh has also beaten bladder and prostate cancer. He said he was injured on the job in 2002 and was diagnosed with cancer a year later. Over the years, his medical bills have piled up. Marsh, who works 14 hours a week and makes $10 an hour, said life has become overwhelming. "One night, I fell to my knees and said, 'Lord, would you please help me?' I was laying in my bed, tears rolling down my eyes, and my pillow was soaking wet," said Marsh. With the help of a friend, Marsh created a GoFundMe page . In less than 24 hours, he raised $20,000. John Keating is one customer who developed a relationship with Marsh over the years. "When you're John Marsh and you have that warm smile and firm handshake, and you have that gift of remembering everybody's name, that's powerful," said Keating. "If you're having a bad day, go through the McDonald's drive-thru and you'll get cheered up right away. He'll reach out to give you that handshake and remember something about you." Watch the story from KXAS here. Filed under:

thread.title: McDonald’s Response to $15 Minimum Wage: Automation in Every Store
thread.title_full: McDonald’s Response to $15 Minimum Wage: Automation in Every Store

posts.author: Bob Adelmann
posts.title: McDonald’s Response to $15 Minimum Wage: Automation in Every Store
posts.text:
Email 
It’s official: McDonald’s says that every one of its 14,000 stores nationwide will be replacing cashiers with automated touch-screen kiosks. They’re starting with stores where minimum-wage laws mandate the highest rates, such as Florida, New York, San Francisco, Boston, Chicago, Washington, D.C., and Seattle. 
According to CNNMoney : So the fast food giant is rolling out self-order kiosks, mobile pay options, an updated interior design, even table service. The changes are already starting to show up at locations in Florida, New York and Southern California, where 500 restaurants have been updated. Restaurants in San Francisco, Boston, Chicago, D.C. and Seattle will get upgrades in early 2017. Now, McDonald's loyalists will be able to place their customized order on a touch screen, take a seat and have their meal brought right over. Next year, they'll even have the option of mobile ordering. 
That means that, eventually, more than 20 million customers every day will place their own orders at a kiosk or on a mobile device and then have them delivered by a human to their table. And it’s just a matter of time before those humans will be replaced by machines as well. 
Ed Rensi started as a grill man for McDonald’s in Columbus, Ohio, in 1966. He was promoted to manager within a year and continued to be promoted, all the way up to president and chief operating officer in 1984. In 1991, he was named chief executive officer and retired to a life of speaking professionally about his experiences in 2007. 
In May, Rensi was asked about the discussion over raising the minimum wage. He responded: “I guarantee you if a $15 minimum wage goes across the country you’re going to see a job loss like you can’t believe. It’s cheaper to buy a $35,000 robot than it is to hire an employee who’s inefficient making $15 an hour bagging French fries.” 
It’s all about the math. Rensi oversaw every aspect of McDonald’s: sales, profits, operations, customer satisfaction, product development, personnel, and training. If a store can replace a $15 an hour employee with a robot that costs $35,000, it will not only improve that store’s operating margins but will actually enhance customer experience: robots don’t get sick, they don’t have attitudes or get pregnant, they don’t go on strike, they always show up for work on time, and, as software improves, will provide a friendly, interactive interface with the store. 
McDonald’s decision will also answer, finally and forever, the question that economics textbooks and economics professors have been raising and then trying to answer for decades: What impact will raising the minimum wage have? Supporters of minimum-wage laws say that they increase the standard of living of workers, reduce poverty, reduce inequality, and boost the economy as well as the morale of workers. 
Opponents say minimum-wage laws increase unemployment and poverty and are especially damaging to small businesses that are forced to raise their prices to cover the increased labor costs. 
Here’s the math: a worker being paid $15 an hour costs his employer $38,500 a year, including unemployment insurance and the employer’s part of Social Security. If Rensi is right, and the average robot in a McDonald’s costs $35,000, in less than a year that store has paid for it in reduced wages, and eliminates that $15 an hour cost forever after. If there are 30 employees in a McDonald’s, and if just 10 of them are replaced by a robot, customers will enjoy another benefit: lower prices on their Happy Meals. 

An Ivy League graduate and former investment advisor, Bob is a regular contributor to The New American magazine and blogs frequently at LightFromTheRight.com, primarily on economics and politics. thread.title: Obama administration says overtime rule is legal, despite judge's order
thread.title_full: Obama administration says overtime rule is legal, despite judge's order

posts.author: Dave Boyer
posts.title: Obama administration says overtime rule is legal, despite judge's order
posts.text:
More... FILE - In this Thursday, Dec. 5, 2013, file photo, protestors demonstrate outside a McDonald’s restaurant in Oakland, Calif. A federal court on Tuesday, Nov. 22, 2016, blocked implementation of a rule imposed by President Barack Obama’s administration that would ... more > View Comments Print By Dave Boyer - The Washington Times   
The Obama administration says its regulation mandating overtime pay for millions of workers is legal, despite a federal judge’s decision that blocks the rule from taking effect. 
“We strongly disagree with the decision by the court, which has the effect of delaying a fair day’s pay for a long day’s work for millions of hardworking Americans,” the Department of Labor said in a statement. “The department’s overtime rule is the result of a comprehensive, inclusive rulemaking process, and we remain confident in the legality of all aspects of the rule.” 
The statement said the administration is “currently considering all of our legal options.” 
U.S. District Judge Amos Mazzant of the Eastern District of Texas, who was appointed by President Obama, issued a nationwide injunction against the rule Tuesday at the request of 21 states, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and other business groups. It would have made more than 4 million private-sector workers eligible for overtime or time off, beginning on Dec. 1. 
The liberal Center for American Progress, which is closely aligned with the White House, said the ruling increases the likelihood that President-elect Donald Trump will dump the overtime rule completely next year. 
“By enjoining the rule, the Eastern District has made it easy for Republicans to wipe the rule away completely once President-elect Donald Trump takes office,” said CAP senior vice president Angela Kelley. “One judge has prevented millions of Americans, who are not currently guaranteed overtime protections, from getting a much needed raise.” 
Industry hailed the decision as a needed check against the administration’s executive overreaching on costly regulations. 
The Labor Department’s change to the overtime rule required employers to pay time-and-a-half to employees who worked more than 40 hours per week and earned less than $47,476 a year. 
The salary threshold is about twice the current exemption from overtime pay. 
The judge said the Labor Department regulation exceeded the authority granted it by Congress. He said the department has the right to define which workers are considered salaried, but only based on the duties performed, not by how much they are paid. 
Debra Ness, president of the National Partnership for Women & Families, called the judge’s ruling “an appalling overreach that must not stand.” 
“By updating wage and hour protections that had been allowed to erode for decades, the new rule would help stop an egregious form of worker abuse and put fair wages in the hands of millions of workers who labor at their jobs for more than 40 hours per week,” she said.

posts.text:
Share This 
A couple of McDonald’s co-workers in Connecticut were at the end of their shift when they noticed two nasty people engaging in intercourse right outside the restaurant in plain sight. However, their sex acts weren’t all that the shocked employees saw. They were sickened by what was between the two and called the police to report it. 28-year-old Kimberly Onorato (left), McDonald’s (center), 27-year-old Rory Clark (right) 
While diners inside a West Haven McDonald’s restaurant were trying to eat, 27-year-old Rory Clark and 28-year-old Kimberly Onorato were caught up in their sex acts right outside the window, which nobody needed to see. If the intercourse wasn’t disgusting enough, what else was there made it much worse, which some employees saw as they were leaving their shift around 9:30 p.m. that night. 
There’s nothing romantic about McDonald’s or their parking lot, but that didn’t matter to the amorous pair who found a connection with each otherÂ there and decided to consummate it in public. However, it wasn’t just the unfortunate onlookers that were watching, the couple had a 6-year-old child in common between them that was forced to be a spectator of their sex acts from the backseat of the car they were all in, according to the New York Daily News . 
The employees leaving work immediately called 911 mostly with regard to the fact that there was a child forced into this sickening situation. When officers arrived, the partially undressed couple said that they were just “cuddling” after enjoying their McDonald’s meal, although it was clear to everyone in and out of the car that they were having sex in front of this kid. 
Clark and Onorato were arrested and charged with second-degree breaches of peace and impairing the morals of a minor. It’s unclear if the child belongs to the man, woman, or both, but this predatory pair should also be hit with child abuse for what they forced upon this 6-year-old, who was reportedly “alert and awake” for the entire ordeal. Clearly, this couple has no control over their urges if they’re willing to drop their pants in public at a McDonald’s with a kid in tow, which leaves one to wonder what other dirty deeds this child has seen.

posts.title: Swedish woman refuses to leave McDonald’s for 3 weeks
posts.text:
Swedish woman refuses to leave McDonald’s for 3 weeks while searching for permanent home Swedish woman refuses to leave McDonald’s for 3 weeks A Swedish woman has taken up residence inside a McDonald's while she searches for a more permanent home in the surrounding area. (Paul Sakuma/AP)  25 PM 
She won’t McLeave. 
For the last three weeks, an unnamed woman has taken up residence in a Swedish McDonald’s with the hope of finding a more permanent place to live in her spare time, according to local news reports. 
She reportedly travelled to the city of Velanda, where she hopes to live, and then camped out inside the fast-food chain. 
“We have opened around the clock and it’s warm in the building,” an employee explained to a local newspaper . “We tried to speak to her about how she can’t stay here, but it hasn’t worked. She keeps coming back.” McDonald's around the world 
Earlier this week, employees reported her for trespassing after she tried to re-enter the restaurant — still though she remained at the eatery, even after police officers offered to buy her a train ticket back to her hometown. Instead, she hopes to live in Velanda in spite of having no friends or family there because she knows the area well. 
“We have tried everything, the social services, security, police, the church, the women’s shelter,” the McDonald’s employee continued. “We want to get rid of her but she’s still living here. It’s clearly frustrating.” Join the Conversation:

thread.title: On anniversary of McDonald video release, no sign of federal case
thread.title_full: On anniversary of McDonald video release, no sign of federal case | Chicago Sun-Times

posts.author: suntimes.com
posts.title: On anniversary of McDonald video release, no sign of federal case
posts.text:
Shortly after Laquan McDonald was killed in a hail of bullets by Chicago Police Officer Jason Van Dyke in October 2014, U.S. Attorney Zachary Fardon huddled with Cook County State’s Attorney Anita Alvarez and the FBI to discuss their parallel investigations of the shooting.
Van Dyke is now facing a murder charge in Cook County criminal court, and a Cook County grand jury is investigating whether officers lied in their reports.
What’s less clear is where Fardon’s investigation stands today. One year after his office insisted its investigation “remains active and ongoing,” the federal probe now appears to be on hold.
But former federal prosecutor and Chicago Police Board President Lori Lightfoot shared a different theory Monday during a Better Government Association panel about the legacy of the McDonald shooting on police reform.
“By early December 2014, that case was with the U.S. attorney’s office and the FBI. And then nothing happened,” Lightfoot said. “So frankly, one of the questions that we got to ask ourselves is, what happened with the U.S. attorney’s office? Why is it that now, two years later, nothing’s happened? Now, I think the truth is, that we can all conclude — and there are many former prosecutors here in the room — we know what happened, which is that case got closed.”
She said the U.S. attorney’s office “didn’t do its job.” And when asked why, Lightfoot responded, “I think that’s a question that you’re going to have to ask my friend and former colleague, Zach Fardon, because I think he’s the only one who knows how to answer it.”
A spokesman for the U.S. attorney’s office wouldn’t comment. But Fardon addressed the McDonald case — without mentioning it by name — during a Sept. 26 speech to the City Club. Fardon discussed the interplay between state and federal prosecutors, and he suggested his office is waiting to see how Cook County’s prosecution plays out.
“When the state decides to charge an officer, my office often will wait rather than risk jamming up the state’s prosecution,” Fardon said. “When we make that decision to wait, we monitor the state case to see how it is resolved, and once the state case is done, we make a decision whether or not to charge federally. In making that decision, the key factor is whether we the think the state result, including any prison sentence, has rendered justice.”
Fardon also said there are times when, even if his office has enough evidence to prosecute, he’ll defer to state authorities. He said double jeopardy laws could kick in — and interfere with a state prosecution — if he charges someone first. And the state’s murder and manslaughter charges carry a heavier penalty.
“The state often carries a bigger criminal stick than the feds” when it comes to the use of excessive force by police officers, Fardon said. “Whether we like it or not, that’s the reality.”
An attorney for Van Dyke didn’t respond to a request for comment.
Cook County Judge Leroy Martin Jr. recently appointed Patricia Brown Holmes as a special prosecutor to investigate whether officers lied to cover up for Van Dyke. Holmes, a former Cook County associate judge and former assistant U.S. attorney, may also look into the conduct of the officers’ supervisors.
A dashboard camera on a police vehicle provided video showing Van Dyke firing at McDonald on Oct 20, 2014 while the troubled 17-year-old walked away with a knife in his hand — contradicting officers’ reports that McDonald lunged at police with the knife.
Chicago Police Supt. Eddie Johnson has moved to fire Van Dyke, along with three officers and a sergeant who he has found lied about the shooting.
The Cook County state’s attorney had opened a criminal investigation on Nov. 4, 2014 after obtaining a copy of the video of the shooting. Fardon then met with Alvarez and the head of the FBI on Dec. 8, 2014 and a federal investigation was opened, authorities said.
On April 15, 2015, the City Council voted to pay McDonald’s family a $5 million legal settlement, before the family even filed a lawsuit. It wasn’t until a year ago — on Nov. 24, 2015 — that the city released the controversial shooting video to the public and Alvarez charged Van Dyke with murder.

posts.title: Couple accused of having sex in McDonald’s parking lot as 6-year-old watched | New York's PIX11 / WPIX-TV
posts.text:
Email 
ORANGE, Conn. – Two McDonald’s employees called police after walking out of the restaurant to find a couple in a parked car “engaged in sexual activity,” police said Monday. 
The workers had just finished their shifts at the Orange, Connecticut, McDonald’s around 9:30 p.m. on November 15, when they noticed the vehicle. One of the employees told a 911 operator it appeared the pair were having sex, and that “a small child was seated in the back, watching,” according to police. Kimberly Onorato, 28, and Rory Clark, 27, allegedly told police that they were “cuddling” after two McDonald’s employees called 911 to report two people engaged in sexual activity in the parking lot. (Town of Orange Police Department) 
When police arrived, they found a woman partially-naked in the front seat with a man, and a 6-year-old in the back seat who was “alert and awake,” WTIC reported. 
The couple said they were “cuddling” after eating at McDonald’s, according to police. 
Officers arrested Rory Clark, 27, of West Haven, and Kimberly Onorato, 28, of Bristol. Both were charged with second-degree breach of peace and impairing the morals of a minor. 
They were both released on $5,000 bond.

posts.title: Couple Faces Charges After Alleged McDonald's Parking Lot Car Sex
posts.text:
Orange Police/Cosmopolitan Fewer things seem less like an aphrodisiac than a quarter-pounder with cheese, but apparently such is not the case for everyone: A Connecticut couple is facing charges after police say they engaged in sexual activity in a parked car with a 6-year-old boy in the back seat.
Police in the town of Orange, Connecticut say two McDonald's employees were leaving the restaurant on Nov. 15 when they spotted two people engaged in sexual activity in the front seats of a car. They say the child was in the back seat, awake and alert.
Police say they arrived to find 28-year-old Kimberly Onorato partially undressed. Police say Onorato and 27-year-old Rory Clark stated they had only been cuddling after eating a meal at McDonald's.
Clark and Onorato are both charged with impairing morals of a minor and breach of peace. Online court records don't list lawyers for the pair. Clark was released after posting a $5,000 bond and is due back in court on Dec. 15; Onorato was also released after posting $5,000 bond and is due in court on Dec. 8.
The child was turned over to a relative. Police also contacted child welfare authorities. A public service announcement for anyone else out there whose Happy Meal has put them in the mood for a happy ending: There are better places to get it on than a McDonald's parking lot and better ways to do it than in front of a little kid, for example anywhere else and any other way.
Additional reporting by the Associated Press.
Follow Hayley on Twitter .

thread.title_full: A Rare Bankruptcy for a McDonald's Franchisee

posts.author: Investopedia
posts.title: A Rare Bankruptcy for a McDonald's Franchisee
posts.text:
A Rare Bankruptcy for a McDonald's Franchisee By Investopedia | November 23, 2016 — 1:47 PM EST 
McDonald's (NYSE: MCD ) apparently only wants big operators serving up fries with that shake as one small franchisee just declared bankruptcy -- a rarity among its operators -- and others have been pushed to sell their handful of locations to bigger franchisees. 
Brown Customer Delight Group, which ran six McDonald's in Iowa, said the restaurants generated gross sales of $7.6 million year to date through August but recorded $4.5 million in losses last year, due in large part to two factors. First, Brown was required by the chain to upgrade its restaurants with such things as double-lane drive-through windows, digital menu boards, and the new equipment required to serve all-day breakfast -- and those stores didn't generate enough revenue to cover the costs of the improvements. Second, the parent chain opened several new, competing McDonald's in its markets. 
BCDG reported having about $15.6 million in liabilities but just $6.7 million in assets. 
According to Nation's Restaurant News, bankruptcies among McDonald's franchisees are a relatively rare occurrence because the agreement franchisees sign tends to discourage them. Instead, it pushes for selling stores to another franchisee. BCDG is hoping McDonald's will buy its restaurants from it, though the fast-food chain's refranchising push might make that unlikely, even though it is only a half dozen restaurants. 
Approximately 85% of McDonald's are owned by franchisees, but the burger king expects to sell about 4,000 company-owned restaurants to franchisees through 2018, en route to its long-term goal of becoming 95% franchised. 
BloombergBusinessweek , however, reports McDonald's is also seeking to squeeze out the little guys like BCDG that own just a handful of restaurants. It says since 2014, the number of U.S. franchisees has fallen by 2.6%, even though the number of franchised locations has grown 1.2%, suggesting more restaurants are being consolidated into fewer hands. 
Although McDonald's has long had a reputation for championing the expansion of small owners who have just one or two stores, as the burger chain has sought to reverse its loss of customers, it has made expensive changes such as those that dogged BCDG, and apparently feels bigger operators will be better able to finance the costs. 
While bankruptcies among McDonald's franchisees may still be rare, we may start to see more of them if the chain's restaurant don't start generating more foot traffic -- or at the least, we'll see the big guys continue to swallow smaller ones.

ORANGE, Conn. (AP) — A Connecticut couple is facing charges after police say they engaged in sexual activity in a parked car with a 6-year-old boy in the back seat. 
Police in Orange say two McDonald’s employees were leaving the restaurant on Nov. 15 when they spotted two people engaged in sexual activity in the front seats of a car. They say the child was in the back seat, awake and alert. 
Police say they arrived to find 28-year-old Kimberly Onorato partially undressed. Police say Onorato and 27-year-old Rory Clark stated they had only been cuddling. 
Clark and Onorato are both charged with impairing morals of a minor and breach of peace. Online court records don’t list lawyers for the pair. 
The child was turned over to a relative. Police also contacted child welfare authorities.
